string.text: A robust steel helmet manufactured in the same Ukrainian factories as the exoskeleton armors. It features an integrated British SF10 gas mask, widely available on surplus markets following its replacement by the General Service Respirator (GSR). The helmet offers substantial protection against ballistic impacts and shrapnel, making it suitable for high-risk operations in the Zone. Its design ensures compatibility with most exoskeleton models, providing a comprehensive defense solution.

An aluminium/titanium helmet with a cloth exterior for camouflage. It includes pockets for additional armor inserts, enhancing its protective capabilities. This helmet is commonly used by military stalkers and Spetsnaz, often paired with PSZ-series body armor. The Sphere M12 Helmet provides excellent combat-oriented protection, making it one of the most reliable choices in the Zone.

An outdated steel army helmet with a retractable visor. It offers basic protection against ballistic threats and shrapnel. Commonly found in surplus markets, it's often used by rookie stalkers seeking affordable head protection. Despite its age, it provides a reliable option for relatively low-threat environments.

A high-quality helmet made by the same Defense Research Institute that produced the SSP-99 and SEVA bodysuits. It allows for complete isolation from the conditions of an anomalous environment. A closed-cycle air filtration system supplies the wearer with consistently cool, clean air. This helmet is well-suited for extended operations in highly contaminated zones.

A ShMB gas mask refitted with external 40mm filters for greater functionality. Generally, masks like this offer respectable protection in areas of increased radioactivity, but suffer from a high failure rate in toxic environments. This refit improves its usability but does not fully mitigate its weaknesses.

A basic plastic and rubber respirator, used to protect the wearer from inhaling harmful dusts, fumes, vapors, or gases. Widely used by rookies due to its light weight and economical environmental protection. However, it provides negligible physical protection and is guaranteed to fail in more heavily irradiated areas.

A GP-5 gas mask, a model originally designed to protect the Soviet populace from radioactive fallout. The filters of this GP-5 have been restored with a great deal of care. Compared to gas mask kits of similar price and availability, this reconditioned device boasts greater protection against radiation but an even higher failure rate in toxic environments.

An ordinary fabric bandana worn by conscripts, support corps, and rear-echelon troops in the Military. Made from simple cotton fabric, it offers minimal protection. Stalkers will often drape it around their mouth and nose to avoid breathing in toxic or radioactive particles, but this protection is unreliable at best.

A regular black fabric balaclava. Made from a blend of cotton and polyester, it provides basic insulation and comfort. Stalkers often use it to cover their mouth and nose to avoid breathing in toxic or radioactive particles, though this protection is unreliable at best.

A simple piece of cloth, folded into a mask. Typically made from cotton or other breathable fabrics. Stalkers use it to cover their mouth and nose to avoid breathing in toxic or radioactive particles, but this protection is unreliable at best.

An M40 model gas mask providing respectable radiation and chemical protection for extended periods. It comes equipped with a multilayered 40-millimetre breathing filter. This durable mask is a reliable choice for those frequently encountering hazardous environments.

Believed to have been created by the faction known as "Final Day", this helmet resembles a Czech M10 Gas Mask with heavy armor plating modifications. When the faction dissolved, these helmets gradually entered into circulation. It offers a balance of respiratory and ballistic protection, favored by veteran stalkers.

A modern, high-quality helmet with a built-in air filtration system based on Western models. The design consists of several layers of Kevlar and composite dielectric materials. Most commonly used by the Zone's Spetsnaz operators, especially in conjunction with the PS5 body armor series. It provides excellent protection and reliability in the field.

A helmet commissioned by extremely influential stalkers, based on the design of the 'Apocalypse' helmet formerly used by the faction "Final Day". This helmet is lighter and more protective than its predecessor, comparing favorably to modern combat helmets such as the 'Sphere' series. It offers enhanced mobility and protection.

A modified version of the standard M12 helmet, designed for use by the Duty faction. Made from aluminium and titanium alloys with a cloth exterior for camouflage. It offers enhanced ballistic protection and integrates with their tactical gear for improved performance in combat.

A special edition of the Duty Sphere M12 helmet featuring reinforced armor and advanced communication systems. Constructed from high-grade aluminium and titanium, with additional protective layers. It is designed for high-risk missions, providing superior protection and situational awareness.
An older model combat helmet used by the Duty faction. Made from durable steel, it provides solid protection and is valued for its durability and reliability in combat situations.

A modern version of the surplus steel helmet, known as the ACH-7 (Advanced Compound Headgear, 7 Parts). Constructed from advanced composite materials for improved ballistic protection. Its lack of a respiratory device makes it an extremely poor choice for the Zone's conditions.

An upgraded version of the ACH-7, including a respiratory system. Made from composite materials with integrated air filtration. The ACH-7EX boasts chemical and radiological protection somewhere between that of a GP-5 and a PBF kit, making it more suitable for Zone conditions.

An EO-21 PBFM gas mask providing enhanced protection against chemical and biological threats. Made with robust rubber and plastic, it is favored by experienced stalkers for its reliability and durable construction.
A specialized version of the EO-21, tailored for the Duty faction. Featuring additional protective layers and improved filtration systems. Suitable for the most hazardous areas of the Zone.
A variant of the EO-21 designed for lightweight and flexible use. Made from rubber and plastic for ease of wear. It offers moderate protection and is ideal for quick deployment scenarios.
A lightweight version of the EO-21 gas mask, customized for the Duty faction. Made from flexible rubber and plastic materials. It combines mobility with adequate protection against airborne threats.

A classic Soviet-era GP-5 gas mask known for its simplicity and effectiveness. Made from rubber with a built-in filter system. Restored to working condition, it offers decent protection against radiation and chemical threats.

A Russian gas mask well suited for CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) ecological hazards. Made from durable rubber and equipped with advanced filtration. In the Zone, it can be considered a functional and spiritual successor to the GP-5, offering enhanced protection and comfort for extended use.

An M50 gas mask tweaked for better functionality in the Zone. Constructed from advanced polymer materials. Overall, it is considered an improvement over the M40, providing superior protection and durability.

A gas mask based on the GP-10, designed primarily to protect the wearer from Controllers and Poltergeists. Made from reinforced rubber with specialized filters. It offers specialized protection against psychic threats, making it a valuable asset in the Zone.

A high-end helmet with reinforced armor and advanced filtration systems. Specifically designed for the Duty faction's elite forces. Made from multiple layers of Kevlar and composite materials, providing exceptional protection in combat.

A warm leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and hiking boots. The outfit of choice among naive or inexperienced stalkers. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A warm leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and hiking boots. Formerly owned by a typical firearm enthusiast, it sports several advantages over an ordinary jacket, namely a camouflage pattern, higher quality material and more pockets to hold belongings. Still an inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A warm leather anorak with an integrated backpack, worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and hiking boots. It seems the previous owner really loved hiking. The educated choice of materials and weight management system makes this more useful than most leather jackets. Still an inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A soft blue leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and hiking boots. These simple suits are assembled in large quantities by Clear Sky's tailors for use within the faction. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A dark leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and combat boots. Formerly used only as relaxed wear for off-duty Dutyers, these simple suits were never intended for use by those on active service. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A black leather jacket commonly associated with the Zone's bandits and crooks. Mostly worn to intimidate rookies from other factions, it provides very little protection. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

Jackets like this first entered circulation among Bandits thanks to Quartermaster Morgan, a corrupt supplier who formerly belonged to the Duty faction. Offers protection comparable to a standard Military service outfit. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n
A snazzy bright red leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and hiking boots. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A camouflaged leather anorak worn over a turtleneck sweater, tucked into jeans and combat boots. Such attire is typically only worn by Freedomers. An inadequate choice for the Zone's harsh conditions.\n \n

A long, heavy overcoat in a brown and dark beige color. The outer layer is made from a durable, water-resistant fabric that shields the wearer from rain and moisture. The interior is lined with a coarse, synthetic material that provides minimal insulation against cold weather. While the overcoat offers basic protection against rain and wind, it lacks any proper protective properties.\n \n

A long, thick overcoat worn over a butchered scientist suit. The outer layer is made from a durable, water-resistant fabric that shields the wearer from rain and moisture. The interior is lined with a coarse, synthetic material providing minimal insulation against cold weather. Although the closed-cycle system and several other features have been stripped off, the end result still compares favorably to many basic stalker suits.

A long, thick green overcoat worn over a butchered scientist suit. The outer layer is crafted from a robust, water-resistant fabric offering protection from rain and moisture. The interior features a coarse, synthetic lining that provides minimal insulation against the cold. Despite the removal of the closed-cycle system and other features, it still compares favorably to many basic stalker suits.

A long, thick overcoat worn over a butchered scientist suit. The exterior is made from a sturdy, water-resistant material that repels rain and moisture. Inside, a coarse, synthetic lining offers minimal insulation against cold weather. While the closed-cycle system and several other features have been stripped off, the end result still compares favorably to many basic stalker suits. The outer shell appears to have some faded bloodstains on it.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The outer layer is made from a durable, water-resistant fabric that provides protection from the elements. The interior is lined with a breathable mesh for comfort during extended wear. This high-quality outfit is intended for extended exploration within the Zone, making it a suit of choice for many artefact and mutant hunters.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The suit features a lightweight outer shell made from a blend of nylon and polyester for flexibility and durability. The interior is padded with high-density foam to provide comfort and slight insulation. This high-quality outfit feels exceptionally light and comfortable to wear, reflecting the craftsmanship and familiarity with the Zone's conditions.

A suit developed and designed by frequent visitors of the 100 Rads and the Barkeep, who supported the project financially. Based on the Sunrise suit, it integrates a common but reliable GP-5 gas mask with lightweight oxygen tanks carried on the back. The suit itself is made from a combination of lead-lined fabric and radiation-resistant materials, offering substantial protection against radioactive environments.

A suit created by the Kiev Defense Research Institute for the purpose of guarding researchers in the Zone. Constructed with budget constraints, it features a blend of Kevlar and ceramic plate inserts for ballistic protection. The outer layer is a heavy-duty, water-resistant fabric. Despite not being officially commissioned, a few of these suits found their way into the Zone, providing decent protection for those who acquired them.

A protective suit, designed and built by local mechanics. This outfit features a lightweight outer shell made from a blend of synthetic fibers for flexibility and durability. It possesses a spacious Class IIIA vest made from aramid fibers and lightweight ceramic inserts for enhanced protection. Essentially, it is a more nimble, stalker-made version of the Berill-5M suit, offering a balance of mobility and defense.

A light suit worn by Clear Sky's novice researchers. The outer layer is constructed from a durable, water-resistant fabric, while the interior is lined with a breathable mesh for comfort. It provides more than adequate protection from the anomalous phenomena found within the Swamps, making it ideal for beginners.

An upgrade to the CS-1 bodysuit intended for conducting rapid search operations in areas of low risk. The suit features a lightweight composite material exterior and enhanced padding for improved mobility and comfort. This design allows for quick movement while still offering sufficient protection against minor threats.

A heavier but still comfortable outfit worn by members of Clear Sky. Made with reinforced Kevlar and ceramic plate inserts, it provides more than adequate protection, especially in combat situations. The suit balances durability with comfort, ensuring wearers are well-protected without sacrificing mobility.

A robust suit formerly issued to Clear Sky assault squads. Constructed from heavy-duty Kevlar with reinforced ceramic plating, it offers excellent protection. After the faction’s infamous failure against the NPP in 2011, this armor serves as a reminder that even an excellent protective bodysuit cannot guarantee safety on the wrong side of the perimeter.

A 'Sunrise' stalker suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing alternative. The suit is constructed from a combination of durable nylon and polyester with reinforced stitching for extra durability. This solid suit is ideal for scavengers on a budget, providing ample storage and decent protection.

A Monolith suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing alternative. Made from heavy-duty synthetic fibers, it offers good resistance to wear and tear. This suit is a cost-effective option for scavengers, balancing practicality and protection.

A CS-2b stalker suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing alternative. Crafted from high-quality, water-resistant fabric, this suit ensures durability and comfort. It’s a solid choice for scavengers on a budget, providing necessary protection and ample storage space.

A Mercenary "Twilight" suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing (LB) alternative. The suit features a rugged, breathable fabric designed to withstand harsh conditions. This practical suit is perfect for budget-conscious scavengers, combining utility with sufficient protection.

A Sentinel of Freedom suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing alternative. Constructed from tough, abrasion-resistant materials, it offers good protection and flexibility. This suit is a reliable option for scavengers looking for a cost-effective yet durable solution.

A PS5-M suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing alternative. Made from a blend of Kevlar and reinforced fabric, it provides excellent protection and durability. This suit is ideal for scavengers on a budget, offering practical storage and reliable defense.

A "Sunset" bandit suit with the vest switched out for a special pocketed load-bearing (LB) alternative. The suit is constructed from high-strength synthetic materials, ensuring durability and flexibility. This budget-friendly suit is suitable for scavengers, providing essential protection and storage options.

An old IBA (Interceptor Body Armor) suit imported from the West and modified for the Zone's conditions. Constructed with Kevlar and ceramic plate inserts, it offers substantial ballistic protection. The modifications include additional pockets and improved ergonomics for carrying equipment essential for survival in the Zone.

Rumored to be supplied to the Freedom faction directly from an unknown source, this suit is based on the somewhat outdated IBA system. Modified with high-strength synthetic fibers for greater comfort and mobility, it is tailored for the unique conditions of the Zone. Enhanced with modern ballistic plates, it provides reliable protection against most threats.

An Interceptor Anomalous Body Armor System (IBAz) that ended up in the hands of the Military. Compared to the standard model, this suit features ergonomic improvements and includes advanced materials such as Kevlar and lightweight composite plates. It also boasts greater protection against psychic interference, making it well-suited for military operations in the Zone.

An Interceptor Anomalous Body Armor System (IBAz) that ended up in the hands of the Monolith. This suit includes ergonomic enhancements and advanced protective materials, offering superior ballistic protection with Kevlar and composite plates. Additionally, it provides improved defense against psychic interference, a useful property for Monolith operatives.

An old IBA suit imported from the West and modified for the Zone's conditions. The Duty variant is uncomfortably heavy but has received extensive upgrades, including reinforced Kevlar and ceramic armor plates for enhanced protection against ballistic and chemical threats. This suit is designed to withstand the harshest conditions encountered by Duty members.

A well-kept Interceptor Anomalous Body Armor System (IBAz) sold directly to the Mercenaries from various Western sources. Constructed with high-strength Kevlar and ceramic plates, it offers superior ballistic protection. While a bit uncomfortable, this suit is overall more advanced and protective than the standard models circulating in the Zone.

A strong but somewhat outdated combat suit. Made from durable synthetic fibers and reinforced with ballistic plates, it offers reliable protection against armed threats. Considered the bare minimum of what should be worn in situations where conflict with armed SSU forces seems inevitable, providing essential defensive properties in hostile environments.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The Sunrise is one of the oldest stalker suits in existence, featuring a durable nylon and polyester blend exterior with reinforced stitching for added durability. It is widely considered the bare minimum protection a stalker should have for serious trips into the Zone.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The "Chameleon" variant includes a camouflaged exterior made from a blend of high-strength synthetic fibers, providing good concealment and moderate protection. It is favored for its ability to blend into the surroundings while offering decent protection in the Zone.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The "Hipster" suit features a unique design with lightweight, breathable fabrics for improved comfort and mobility. It offers basic protection and is popular among those who prioritize style and flexibility over heavy armor.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. For a stalker suit, the "Drought" possesses above-average ballistic protection, utilizing reinforced Kevlar and ceramic plate inserts. However, it is considerably less comfortable to wear due to its heavier and more rigid construction.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. An overall upgrade over the "Drought" suit, the "Predator" features enhanced ballistic protection with Kevlar and lightweight composite plates, and is significantly more comfortable to wear. It enjoys popularity among greenhorns and experts alike thanks to its low maintenance costs and great modification potential.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. Favored among newer artifact hunters and creative hit men, the "Autumn" suit features a chemically resistant outer layer made from specialized synthetic fabrics, allowing easier traversal of chemical anomalous fields.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The "Vineleaf" suit includes a camouflage pattern made from durable synthetic materials, providing both concealment and protection. Its design is optimized for blending into vegetative environments while maintaining moderate ballistic resistance.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. The "Bear" suit's improved protection against ballistics has been achieved through an unnamed home-made anomalous compound, integrated into its Kevlar-reinforced fabric. This suit provides exceptional defense at the cost of added weight and reduced comfort.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. An economical choice with great upgrade potential, the "Salamander" features basic protection with room for enhancements. Ironically, despite its name, it demonstrates a poor ability to safely channel heat, making it less suitable for high-temperature environments.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. Independently designed by a few optimistic stalkers to withstand psy-storms, the "Graphite" suit features a blend of lead-lined fabric and specialized synthetic materials to shelter the wearer's nervous system. Although the original endeavor failed, the recovered designs offer unique protection against psychic threats.

A Zone-built protective suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. One of the heavier stalker suits available, the "Tigerstripe" is designed for those who prefer to make their money as hired killers or fighters. It features reinforced ballistic protection with multiple layers of Kevlar and ceramic plates, making it ideal for combat situations.

A basic suit originally intended as spare equipment for Professor Hermann's "Iskra Scientific Research and Investigation Team". Made from durable synthetic fabrics, it provides moderate protection. It has since become a relatively cheap protective bodysuit for Ecologist guards working all over the Zone.

Unlike other suits in the CS-1, 2, and 3 series, this body armor was only created after the faction's massive losses at the Chernobyl NPP. It features a focus on protecting the wearer from anomalous environments with reinforced materials and advanced filtration systems. Widely considered the first proper successor to the CS-1 suit, it prioritizes safety over armoring for battle.

A Zone-built tactical suit, designed and custom-made by Freedom mechanics. This comfortable bodysuit features a durable, breathable fabric exterior treated with a special solution known as 'Horizon' to increase resistance to chemical anomalies. The interior is lined with moisture-wicking materials, ensuring comfort during extended use in the Zone.

A tactical suit of unknown origins, associated with the Monolith faction. Constructed from high-strength synthetic fibers and reinforced with ballistic plates, it offers substantial protection. Scores of these suits were found in containers and lockers underneath the X18 facility in Dark Valley. There are theories among stalkers that these suits predate the creation of the Zone.

A Zone-built tactical suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. Its design resembles the Monolith X-18 suit but with its conventional NBC features stripped down in favor of greater insulation from thermal and electrical threats. The outer layer is made from heat-resistant and electrically-insulating materials. Mostly used by Bandits in Dark Valley to clear out the poltergeists that occasionally escape from the local lab.

A Zone-built tactical suit, designed and manufactured by local mechanics. Its design resembles a Monolith X-18 suit, featuring a blend of durable synthetic fabrics and reinforced with lightweight ballistic plates. This suit is often salvaged by Mercs from their costly skirmishes in Limansk, providing a balance of protection and mobility.

Sometimes nicknamed the "Nighthunter", this slightly heavy special tactical suit is used by Mercenaries in both nocturnal and urban combat scenarios. Constructed from reinforced Kevlar and ceramic plates, it offers excellent protection while maintaining flexibility for close-quarters combat.

A general purpose protective suit, sometimes nicknamed the "Wolven", a comfortable special tactical suit used by Mercenaries in both exploratory expeditions and stealth operations. Made from lightweight, noise-dampening fabrics and reinforced with ballistic fibers, it provides good protection and exceptional mobility for covert missions.

A UNISG tactical protective suit, based on a standard bodysuit design used by Western special forces. Similar outfits are common to many militaries throughout the world. Constructed from high-strength synthetic fibers and reinforced with Kevlar plates, this is the bare minimum a UNISG operative can expect to be fitted with, offering reliable protection in various combat scenarios.

A special UNISG tactical protective suit. The model is an improvement over the original Mk-1 design, much better suited for the Zone's demanding conditions. Enhanced with additional layers of Kevlar and advanced composite materials, it offers superior protection and comfort. These improvements were commissioned by UNISG based on the limited data recovered from their less fortunate predecessors.

A light combat suit, one of the most common outfits used by the Zone's Mercenaries. Its design is based on suits used by Western special forces, featuring a lightweight Kevlar weave and minimal ceramic plate inserts. Adequate for basic operations, but the quality is lacking when compared to standard Spetsnaz gear. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

A variation of the standard Light Combat outfit, referred to as the "Fighter" by Mercenaries. Made from high-strength synthetic fibers, it is designed for operations requiring stealth and speed. The lightweight construction provides flexibility and comfort, making it ideal for quick, covert missions. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

A light combat suit obtained to armor local Bandit gangs. Based on Western special forces designs, it is constructed from low-quality materials, including substandard Kevlar and poorly assembled ceramic plates. This suit offers minimal protection, highlighting the irony of Bandits being ripped off by their suppliers. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

A light combat suit acquired through dubious means to armor local groups of Renegades. Modeled after Western special forces gear, it features a comfortable and lightweight construction using synthetic fibers and basic ballistic protection. Surprisingly pleasant to wear despite its origins. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

A Mercenary light combat suit modified for use in the Zone. This suit includes reinforced Kevlar layers and additional storage pockets. It is a genuine improvement for newer Mercenaries and serves as a reliable alternative to the faction's special tactical suits. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

An LC-F suit modified and nicknamed the "Scout". Made from lightweight, breathable fabrics with added ballistic protection, it is a very comfortable suit. The modifications make it a good choice for Mercenaries who want to explore the Zone's anomalies on a budget. Many variants are made from this suit's base design.

A light tactical suit, nicknamed "Jackal" after a past leader figure well known among mercenaries. Made from reinforced Kevlar with a sophisticated weight distribution system, it provides excellent comfort and protection. Favored among experienced Mercenaries for its balance of defense and mobility.

A medium tactical suit nicknamed "Coyote". Constructed from advanced composite materials and reinforced with ballistic plates, it is widely considered the successor of the LTS-J body suit. Despite its higher price, most Mercenaries prefer it for its superior protection and comfort.

A comfortable and ergonomic arming suit used to outfit Sin's followers en masse. It consists of a ballistic vest over an environmental bodysuit, made from high-strength synthetic fibers. These suits provide decent protection against ballistic threats and moderate shielding against environmental hazards.

An advanced variant of regular Sin flak armor, typically gifted to the faction's more loyal and devout members. Made from reinforced ballistic materials and featuring enhanced environmental protection. These suits provide decent protection against ballistic threats and moderate shielding against environmental hazards.

A modern, updated variant of the original PS5-M universal protection bodysuit. Made from a blend of Kevlar and advanced composites, it is more than adequate for all of the Zone's conditions and is markedly comfortable for a Duty suit. Initially intended to replace its predecessor entirely, but higher production cost has kept the PS6-V model in use.

A light combat suit model adapted for use by UNISG troops. Based on Western special forces designs, it features high-strength synthetic fibers and basic ballistic protection. Suitable for a variety of operations in the Zone.

A modified light combat suit model adapted for use in the Zone by UNISG troops. Constructed from lightweight, breathable materials and enhanced with camouflage patterns, it is light weight and comfortable. Ideal for reconnaissance and stealth operations.

A modified light combat suit model adapted for urban combat by UNISG troops. Based on Western special forces designs, it features advanced composite materials and reinforced ballistic protection. Compares favorably in combat to many other outfits in its class, but still falls short of what a Spetsnaz operator would be wearing.

A basic outfit contracted by the Ukrainian government in a production effort that was outsourced to the lowest bidder. The outer layer is made from basic synthetic fibers and does not provide any meaningful environmental or ballistic protection. Typically issued to helicopter pilots, tank drivers, rear-echelon personnel, conscripts, and enlisted servicemen. Generally only seen on the outermost perimeter of the Zone where combat is less likely.

An armored suit designed for use by special operations, comprising military PS5 series body armor with beryllium sputter modified for use in the Zone. The suit features advanced composite materials and beryllium coating for enhanced ballistic protection and radiation resistance. Designed for intense rapid-insertion assault operations, this outfit is standard issue for most Spetsnaz operators in the Zone.

A special purpose battle armor, commonly used by Duty faction operatives. This outfit comprises military PS5 series body armor with beryllium sputter modified for use in the Zone. The suit uses high-density ballistic fibers and ceramic plates, offering superior protection and ergonomics compared to a standard PS5-M universal protection suit.

Spetsnaz body armor acquired and repurposed by contracted mercenary mechanics in the Zone. Made from advanced Kevlar and ceramic composites, it provides good physical protection while also being remarkably comfortable to wear. Often worn by mercenaries who used to work for the SSU, this suit balances protection and mobility effectively.

A set of PS5 series body armor with beryllium sputter, acquired through shady means by the Zone's Bandits. Despite showing visible signs of irreparable wear and tear, the suit still offers excellent ballistic protection with its reinforced composite materials and beryllium coating, making it a solid choice for general combat encounters.

A set of Spetsnaz body armor that has been "liberated" for use in the Freedom faction. Treated with "Sovereign", an anomalous compound developed by the faction, it provides enhanced protection against anomalous effects. Its exact composition or anomalous properties have not been documented by Zone researchers. Made from high-strength Kevlar and beryllium-coated composites. When available, the armor is used by Freedom members tasked with defending the barrier and the main faction base against Monolith incursions.

A set of former Spetsnaz body armor, bolstered with more substantial protection. Made from high-density ballistic fibers and reinforced ceramic plates, it offers excellent combat protection. However, it has an infamous failure rate in areas of extreme anomalous activity. Duty veterans often still advocate for the PS5-B2 model's use and are rumored to claim, "you do not need protection from anomalies once you know how to spot them."

An older version of the Duty-developed protective bodysuit, constructed from durable Kevlar and composite materials. It provides balanced protection against ballistic threats and environmental hazards and has a solid balance in cost and utility. Well-suited for recruits who may prefer the familiarity of stalker suits over heavier battle armor models.

An older Duty-developed protective suit developed alongside the PS5-M universal protection outfit. Made from lightweight synthetic fibers and Kevlar, it offers minimal ballistic protection but is designed for mobility. Originally intended to protect Duty scouts in the early days of the Zone's existence, these suits are now mostly retired, kept in reserve for Duty recruits in desperate circumstances.

A Duty-developed heavier variant of the PS5-M universal protection suit, made with reinforced Kevlar and additional padding. It trades some ballistic protection in favor of better defense against common mutant attacks. Specifically designed for Duty units intending to hunt mutants, this suit compares well even to modern Duty suits in its overall properties.

An older, slightly heavier stalker bodysuit designed and manufactured by Freedom mechanics. Constructed from robust synthetic materials and Kevlar, it offers decent protection despite its slightly dated design and some wear and tear on the outside materials. Younger Freedomers value these suits highly, not only for their functionality but also for the stories and legacy they carry.

A modified PS5-M universal protection suit, made from durable Kevlar and composite materials, offering balanced protection. Armor like the PS5-M first entered circulation among Bandits thanks to Quartermaster Morgan, a corrupt supplier formerly associated to the Duty faction. The suit trades some physical protection for greater comfort and defense against anomalies. These suits are a major sore point for the Duty faction, and retrieving them from anarchists and criminals is a high priority.

Based on the PS5-M universal protection suit, the Volos Flak armor is a model manufactured by mechanics of Sin, based off a Duty-developed original design. The armor is made from high-quality Kevlar and composite materials. It is unknown how it came into the possession of Sin, but Duty have voices their concern about their armor designs being appropriated by fanatics and lunatics. The recovery of these suits is an unspoken priority for Duty. Despite the controversy, the suit itself is of good quality and is more than adequate for the Zone's various conditions.

A high quality military-grade armor, designed specifically for combat operations in the Zone. Comprising a PSZ-12p heavy military armored suit, built-in compensation suit, and an anomalous protection bodysuit, it offers exceptional ballistic protection and resistance to environmental hazards. Although originally intended for the sole use of Military stalkers and experienced Spetsnaz operators, this armor occasionally finds its way into factions outside of the Military through unknown means.

A high quality protective bodysuit developed by defense research institutes in Kiev, adopted by Duty faction mechanics. The PSZ-9d body armor features a combination of Kevlar and advanced ceramic plates, providing excellent ballistic protection capable of stopping rifle bullets. Additionally, it offers robust defense against the Zone's anomalous hazards. Typically reserved for Duty members who have proven themselves significantly, this armor is both highly prized and effective.

A high quality intermediate protective bodysuit, with an enhanced design adopted by Duty faction mechanics. The armor is more protective than Duty's regular PS5 universal protection suit, yet less expensive and easier to produce than the PSZ-9d body armor variant. Made from durable composite materials and reinforced with lightweight ballistic fibers, it provides excellent protection for combat encounters. Its ease of maintenance and repair makes it ideal for Duty operatives working far from friendly territory, such as investigators venturing into the northern reaches of the Zone.

A high-end protective suit, adopted by Duty faction mechanics. Made from advanced Kevlar and reinforced with thick ceramic plates, it offers substantial protection against ballistic threats and environmental hazards. The armor is said to have been favored by the late Duty Lieutenant Colonel Shulga. Though Shulga rarely left his operational base in Yanov, he feared assassination and thus preferred heavy protection. He was later presumed dead after leading a mass assault into the city of Pripyat. Veteran Duty operatives occasionally wear models like the PSZ-9kl to honor his legacy.

An intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. The suit is a superior alternative to almost all Zone-made protective suits and offers balanced ballistic, strike, and anomalous protection with moderate weight. Commonly used by experienced research personnel and artifact hunters venturing into hostile territory.

A suit of "Sentinel" body armor produced by Freedom mechanics, built with a robust blend of Kevlar and synthetic fibers. Specially treated materials provide good protection and durability during prolonged exploration of anomalous fields. Designed for observing anomalous phenomena in the Zone, it is a reliable choice for Freedom faction's field researchers.

A Monolith scientific suit that includes a flak vest of unknown origin. It features unique modifications for enhanced radiation resistance at the cost of greater vulnerability to psy-fields. According to reports, similar models are worn by Monolith forces defending the Brain Scorcher in Radar and its southern barrier, deployment can sometimes also be observed in and around Red Forest.

An unofficial variant of the SEVA intermediate level protective suit, a series designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. The CS-4a variant has some internal changes made by Clear Sky faction mechanics to better fit it to the needs of researchers and guard personnel. Like other SEVA variants, it has balanced protection with moderate weight.

An unofficial variant of the SEVA intermediate level protective suit, a series designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest and some additional changes made to the inside linings for added comfort and weight distribution. The SEVA series is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. The Pathfinder model is credited to Clear Sky resident technician Novikov. Compared to many SEVA models, the CS-4a Pathfinder is extremely comfortable to move around in, making it a high-demand suit among Clear Sky and other factions.

An unofficial variant of the SEVA intermediate level protective suit, a series designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest with some custom modifications, as well as replaced internal parts and patched outside materials. This model has been repurposed by bandits, making it one of the higher quality mixed protective outfits commonly used by experienced members. Bandits use these suits to organize ambushes and attacks on stalkers within anomalous fields and radiation pockets, despite their general disinterest in scientific research.

A special design SEVA intermediate level protective suit, a subvariant commissioned by the first iteration of UNISG from the Kiev Defense Research Institute with assistance from experienced mechanics stationed in the Zone. Like other variants, it combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest with some custom modifications. It is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module uses experimental coatings and weaves that aim to provide enhanced protection and durability against radiation and anomalous effects. Some of the changes are hard to determine and the mechanical work on the suit is undocumented.

A SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This particular model was commissioned by mercenaries and customized by local mechanics. The variant features durable synthetic fibers and Kevlar weave. Commonly used by experienced operatives on artifact-hunting contracts. Provides good protection but lacks some more recent psy-protection properties available for modern variants.

A SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class IIIA ballistic vest, a notable upgrade to base models. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This particular variant was commissioned by mercenaries, features higher quality materials and a higher ballistic protection class. The Pathfinder variant was initially produced as a token of goodwill by Clear Sky to help cover rising research costs.

A SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This is a customized Duty variant of the standard SEVA design, adding a durable synthetic weave to augment its overall resistance to anomalous effects (primarily corrosive and thermal). Commonly used by Duty units on exploratory or scientific missions to the northern parts of the Zone.

A lightweight SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class IIIA Kevlar vest, a notable upgrade to the base design. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. The model is a variant of the PS5-9Md Duty base design made with lighter materials and features a higher ballistic protection class, as well as improved weight distribution. Its modifications come with slightly reduced protection against anomalous effects. Commonly used by Duty field researchers and units on exploratory missions.

A lightweight SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This variant has been commissioned by Duty officials for their needs and modified and produced by Clear Sky. It is made from lighter synthetic materials at the expense of some of its protective capabilities. A common choice for Duty field operatives.

A scavenged SEVA intermediate level protective suit, originally designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This variant has been heavily modified and repaired multiple times by Bandit mechanics with mixed materials. The base is made from high-strength materials but repeated changes made to its components reduce its overall protective capabilities. Compared to the base design, it has a lower weight profile. Commonly used by more experienced Bandits and stalkers working on a lower budget.

A SEVA intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This variant has been extensively modified for improved protection against thermal hazards and blunt trauma compared to the standard SEVA design. Commonly used by Renegade members in the northern parts of the Zone. A solid alternative to various other light combat or hand-made suits available.

An intermediate level protective suit designed and produced by the Kiev Defense Research Institute. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. This variant was commissioned by mercenaries and modified to use high-strength synthetic fibers and extra Kevlar weave for added ballistic protection. Commonly used by experienced mercenaries who are contracted to guide high profile research personnel and artifact hunters looking to travel into the more dangerous parts of the Zone.

A SEVA-like intermediate level protective suit built from scratch by unknown mechanics within the Monolith faction. It combines a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit with a specially-treated Class II Kevlar vest. The SEVA is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating against environmental hazards. Compared to commonly traded models, this Monolith variant features high-strength materials and some added ballistic and strike protection at the expensive of the wearer's comfort, alongside average protection against anomalies. Its exact role within the faction is unknown.

An intermediate to high-end level protective suit, one of the most technologically advanced bodysuits in the Zone. The ACE armor system incorporates a next-generation CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit and a pocketed Kevlar vest with Class III plate inserts. Like its less advanced SEVA counter-part, the ACE is designed with a closed-cycle respiratory module. It uses state-of-the-art materials such as selectively-permeable coatings and external treatment for enhanced protection against environmental hazards. The ACE is optimized for maximum anomaly protection for its weight class while also providing high wearer comfort. Only rarely found due to its high cost, used by experienced mercenaries, high-profile researchers, and operatives working on a blank check.

A high-end, current-generation CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) suit, specifically designed for deployment in the exclusion zone. The SSP-99 is crafted from a multi-layered synthetic fabric that offers excellent resistance to chemical and thermal hazards. When combined with the SSP-99 screen helmet, it features an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system. Its closed-cycle respiratory module ensures protection against airborne contaminants. This suit is essential for scientific expeditions into anomalous fields.\n \n

A modified version of the high-end CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) SSP-99 suit with enhanced protective capabilities. The SSP-99M includes a Kevlar underlayer to reduce the risk of puncture of the outer shell. The outer layer is made from a durable synthetic fabric that provides improved resistance to biological anomalies. The integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system ensures breathable air in contaminated environments. This variant is favored by researchers requiring extra protection from biological threats.\n \n

A top-tier version of the high-end CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) SSP-99 suit, designed for maximum environmental protection. The "Diamond" variant features a reinforced synthetic fabric with superior resistance to electrical hazards. It includes an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system when paired with the SSP-99 screen helmet. The closed-cycle respiratory module and enhanced durability in thermal and chemical fields make this suit a widespread choice for extensive research missions in high-risk areas.\n \n

A specialized version of the high-end CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) SSP-99M suit, optimized for effective shielding against psy fields. The "Sapphire" variant includes a Kevlar underlayer to prevent punctures of the outer shell. Its outer layer is composed of high-strength synthetic fabric that shields against short-range psi-emissions. The suit also features an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system for safe breathing in contaminated zones. The Sapphire variant protective suit is commonly used by experienced research personnel in areas known for their high psy fields and high-threat environmental hazards.\n \n

A modified version of the SSP-99M suit designed for enhanced melee protection. The "Ruby" includes a Kevlar underlayer to reduce the risk of puncture from hostile mutants. Its reinforced synthetic fabric provides additional defense against melee attacks. An integrated wound healing system offers immediate medical support in the field. This suit is preferred by researchers facing physical threats in the exclusion zone.\n \n

A version of the high-end CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) SSP-99 suit, optimized for increased radiation protection. The "Topaz" variant features a synthetic fabric blend that provides superior resistance to radiological hazards. When combined with the SSP-99 screen helmet, it includes an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system. The suit's closed-cycle respiratory module ensures safety in highly irradiated environments. The model is commonly used by researchers exploring the most highly irradiated areas of the Zone and require effective protection against a variety of environmental hazards.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. This variant has been customized by Duty mechanics for use in combat. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This suit is typically found in the hands of elite Duty units, especially those assigned to guard VIPs or launch exceedingly dangerous raids on enemy factions or push into the northern parts of the Zone. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. This variant has been customized by Freedom mechanics for use in combat. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. Only used by highly experienced members of Freedom, rarely used as-is in the field. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. This variant has been customized by Mercenary mechanics. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. In contrast to other exosuit variants, the Mercenary variant is more commonly worn by high-profile operatives and bodyguards of contractors requiring top of the line ballistic protection. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A scavenged and worn heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit shows numerous signs of past repair and appears to have had some of its parts replaced entirely. Provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. The scavenged variant is imposing in its rough appearance but cheaper to maintain than other used models. A favorite among the Zone's most experienced outlaws. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". This variant has been modified extensively by Monolith mechanics. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support, some of its parts have been swapped for heavier alternatives that also reduce the wearer's freedom of movement on the inside. Commonly used by Monolith combat units guarding and defending major points of interest in the Zone. Notes found from Monolith followers consistently claim that the confines of the suit feels as comforting as the Sarcophagus at the heart of the Zone.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, customized for common military use, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. Although commissioned by the Ukrainian government, the military variant exosuit is considered too cumbersome for general adoption and have never been widely issued. Some military stalkers may still seek to acquire it through other means.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This model is a customized variant by Clear Sky with the intent of enabling a wider adoption of the exosuit, as well as sale and distribution to other factions. Some of the inner parts have been replaced with lighter, more comfortable alternatives compared to the base design.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, customized for common military use, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. Similar to the military variant, this model was originally commissioned by the Ukrainian government, and later adopted and further changed for use by UNISG forces. They were issues to units in the field but also never widely adopted. Most ISG operatives prefer increased mobility over the raw protective capabilities of exosuits.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton, in a woodland camo pattern. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. The woodland variant includes a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit lined with Kevlar. The intent of the rare model and its general adoption is unknown.

A scavenged and worn heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The suit shows numerous signs of past repair and appears to have had some of its parts replaced entirely. Provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. The scavenged variant is imposing in its rough appearance but cheaper to maintain than other used models. A favorite among the Zone's most experienced outlaws. Due to the unavailability of powered heavy duty exoskeletons, the exosuit may be worn as-is.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The "Hero of Freedom" variant was developed on the exosuit base design by Freedom mechanics to achieve a more widespread adoption. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This variant includes a dated CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit lined with Kevlar weave and has an additional attachment slot.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The PSZ-10d variant was developed on the exosuit base design by Duty mechanics to achieve a more widespread adoption. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This variant includes a dated CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit lined with Kevlar weave and has an additional attachment slot. Used by elite Duty units for VIP escort missions or for dangerous defense and attack missions.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The PSZ-10d Venator variant was developed on the preceding PSZ-10d design by Duty mechanics. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. Used by experienced Duty units for defense, procurement, and hunting missions in mixed environments.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The PSZ-10l Forest variant was developed on the PSZ-10d design by Duty mechanics. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This variant includes a dated CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) jumpsuit lined with Kevlar weave and steel reinforcements. Used by experienced Duty units, particularly for expeditionary missions to the northern reaches of the Zone.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The PSZ-10g Urban variant was developed on the PSZ-10 base design by Duty mechanics. The suit provides high ballistic and strike protection but its raw bulk is not balanced against its capabilities without additional weight support. This variant does not provide meaningful protection against environmental hazards. The design is somewhat dated, models like the Urban were used by Duty in the assault on the Monolith-occupied city of Pripyat and the clash with Freedom in 2012.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The TB-1 variant was developed on the exosuit base design by mercenary mechanics and features a synthetic fiber weave for added durability and flexibility. Used by highly experienced mercenary units looking to operate in the most dangerous parts of the Zone.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". The Urban variant was developed by mercenary mechanics, intended for short-term deployment, a counter-part to the Woodland variant. The model offers no significant protection against environmental hazards, focusing solely on close-quarter combat. Commonly used by highly experienced mercenary units and bodyguards of mercenary companies operating in the urban areas of the Zone, like Limansk or Pripyat.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". It includes a basic CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) layer. The woodland variant was developed by mercenary mechanics with the intent to create a high-end protective suit with more widespread adoption, a counter-part to the Urban variant. Used by mercenaries requiring heavy protection in the many forested areas of the Zone.\n \n

A heavy ballistic vest containing Class IV plates, reinforced with steel with many of the attachment points needed for a rigid exoskeleton. However, with no powered exoskeleton to ease the load, this armor is cumbersome to wear for extended periods of time. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". It includes a basic CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear) layer. The woodland variant was developed by mercenary mechanics with the intent to create a high-end protective suit with more widespread adoption, a counter-part to the Urban variant. Used by mercenaries requiring heavy protection in the flatter grassland areas of the Zone.\n \n

A high-end "Sunrise" bodysuit specially designed to be fitted with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. This setup allows the wearer to carry significantly more equipment than under normal circumstances. The suit is crafted from a blend of high-strength synthetic fibers, offering moderate protection. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it provides less protection but is considerably lighter. Commonly used by stalkers needing increased carrying capacity without the bulk of a full exo.\n \n

A high-end "Wind of Freedom" bodysuit designed to be fitted with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. This configuration enables the wearer to carry significantly more equipment. The suit is made from a lightweight, durable synthetic fabric, providing moderate protection. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it is lighter and less cumbersome. Commonly used by Freedom members for its balance of mobility and capacity.\n \n

A high-end PS5-M type universal protection bodysuit designed to be fitted with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. This setup allows the wearer to carry significantly more equipment. The suit features a durable Kevlar weave for added defense against ballistic threats. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it offers less protection but is notably lighter. Used by Duty members who need enhanced carrying capacity without sacrificing too much mobility.\n \n

A high-end PSZ-9d type armored bodysuit designed to be fitted with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. The base exosuit is also known as the "Radsuit". This variant sacrifices some ballistic protection for greater functionality in anomalous fields. The suit is made from high-strength synthetic materials and includes a Kevlar underlayer for added durability. Ideal for Duty operatives conducting missions in highly anomalous areas.\n \n

A high-end Skat-9 type bodysuit, the very first iteration of the common military exoskeleton, designed to fit with the servos and batteries of a modern exoskeleton. This suit sacrifices some ballistic protection for greater functionality in anomalous fields. Constructed from durable synthetic fibers, it includes reinforced plating for additional defense. This prototype is used for military operations requiring both enhanced carrying capacity and maneuverability.\n \n

An experimental X-18 type exoskeleton, developed by Monolith mechanics with the assistance of an unknown manufacturer, designed to be fitted with servos and batteries. The suit allows the wearer to carry significantly more equipment, and features a high-strength synthetic fabric that provides moderate protection. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it is lighter and less protective. Used by Monolith members requiring increased capacity in the field.\n \n

A high-end CS-2b type body armor set modified to fit with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. This configuration allows the wearer to carry significantly more equipment. The suit is constructed from a durable synthetic fabric with additional Kevlar reinforcements for moderate protection. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it provides less protection but is considerably lighter. Used by Clear Sky operatives looking for enhanced mobility and load-bearing capacity.\n \n

A unique high-end armor system composed of an SSP-99M protective jumpsuit, powered by an exoskeleton frame. The suit includes a Class IIA Kevlar vest, specially treated for extra environmental protection. The durable exo-frames provide mechanical support, enabling the wearer to carry heavy loads through anomaly fields. Used by highly experienced researchers and guard personnel on deep incursion missions into the Zone.\n \n

A UN-branded high-end special tactical bodysuit, designed to be fitted with the servos and batteries of an exoskeleton. This setup allows the wearer to carry significantly more equipment. The suit is made from high-strength synthetic fibers, providing moderate protection. Compared to a full exoskeleton, it offers less protection but is considerably lighter. Used by UNISG operatives for tactical operations requiring enhanced load-bearing capacity.\n \n

A high-tech military exoskeleton consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, carried by powered limbs and servomotors. The suit's durable materials provide significant protection, though it was never mass-produced due to high costs, the need for an active power supply using proprietary batteries, and some flaws in its overall design. The PSZ-10 is the common base model armor without any additional customizations, a framework in the development of the military variant. Commonly used by highly experienced units requiring advanced protective gear in the most dangerous reaches of the Zone or used as the base for further modification by capable mechanics.\n \n

A high-tech exoskeleton armor, featuring a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, all carried by powered limbs and servomotors. The model has been developed off the exoskeleton base design by Duty mechanics together with military technicians for widespread use in the field. The suit provides excellent protection and durability. Although highly effective, many Duty members opt out of heavy exoskeleton armor for more comfortable and less expensive alternatives. Commonly used by Duty's most experienced units in high-risk missions in the most dangerous reaches of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech exoskeleton armor, consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The model has been developed and extensively customized off the exoskeleton base design by mechanics of Freedom. Though not practical to maintain, it offers formidable power and protection. Although highly effective, many members of Freedom opt out of heavy exoskeleton armor for more comfortable and less expensive alternatives. Commonly used by highly experienced Freedom members in critical operations in the most dangerous reaches of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech military exoskeleton armor of western production, featuring a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, all carried by powered limbs and servomotors. The PSZ-M is an advanced variant of the common exoskeleton base design, optimized for more comfortable and long-term use by contracted mechanics. While everyday maintenance can be challenging, the suit allows the wearer to be heavily armed and well-armored, with the strength to carry significant supplies. Commonly used by highly experienced mercenaries, leading their units in the most dangerous reaches of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech experimental exoskeleton armor, consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. In comparison to the common exoskeleton design, this variant has been heavily modified by Monolith technicians, featuring some unknown materials added to the interior of the shell, likely for added shielding. Studied samples reveal that its servos are reinforced with an unknown alloy. Due to the added bulk, the Monolith variant suit is somewhat claustrophobic, though the followers of the Monolith are reported to find its cramped feeling comforting. Commonly used by the most experienced followers of the Monolith in the northern reaches of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech military exoskeleton armor, consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The variant has been heavily customized by bandit mechanics and many of the parts of the original armor design have been swapped for cheaper alternatives. This armor is favored by aspiring outlaws as a symbol of strength and authority. Commonly used by experienced bandits in raids and high-stakes confrontations or for incursions into the northern reaches of the Zone.\n \n

An official military class high-tech exoskeleton armor, released and distributed in limited quantities to stationed military units operating in the Zone. The suit includes a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. Designed to carry heavy weapons and supplies, it is occasionally used in place of light vehicles. The PSZ-10m has been lightly customized from the base design by military technicians to improve performance in the field. Commonly used by Military stalkers in extended operations and high-risk missions in the most dangerous parts of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech experimental exoskeleton armor, customized and refurbished by Clear Sky technicians for widespread adoption and distribution. The suit features a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, all carried by powered limbs and servomotors. The variant is based off the official military exoskeleton design, with major modifications to electronic components and protective weaving used in the outer materials. The intent of the CS-5 iteration was to develop a more widely available active armor system that could be manufactured inside the exclusion zone. Its full potential was never achieved and the commonly traded variant still has many of the flaws of the original design. Used by highly experienced Clear Sky operatives for extended expeditions.\n \n

An official military class high-tech exoskeleton armor, released and distributed in limited quantities to stationed military units operating in the Zone. The suit includes a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. Designed to carry weapons, supplies, and heavy research equipment. The PSZ-10x has been lightly customized from the base design by military technicians together with materials scientists to improve performance and environmental protection. Commonly used by experienced researchers in expeditions to the most dangerous parts of the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech exoskeleton armor, consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The variant has been mostly scavenged from spare parts from different exoskeleton armors and appears to have some additional makeshift modifications by Renegade technicians. Commonly worn by experienced Renegade members in defense missions, coordinated raids, and high-stakes confrontations.\n \n

An official military class high-tech exoskeleton armor, released and distributed in limited quantities to ISG units operating in the Zone. The suit includes a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. Designed to carry heavy weapons and supplies, it is occasionally used in place of light vehicles. The PSZ-10z is a rare model that has been customized off the original base design in UN-funded defense facilities, optimized for extended use and increased comfort. Commonly used by UNISG operatives in reconnaissance and tactical missions.\n \n

A custom high-tech experimental exoskeleton armor, consisting of a steel-reinforced Kevlar jumpsuit and a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The variant has modified and refurbished and appears to feature a number of additional makeshift modifications and by technicians of Sin, including some identifying markings on the outer shell. Study samples reveal its servos are made from unknown alloys and materials. Wearing this suit induces an unnatural feeling of bliss and calm. Commonly worn by experienced members of Sin.\n \n

A high-tech, next-generation exoskeleton armor, featuring a double-reinforced Kevlar exosuit, a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, and an additional layering of ballistic-weave, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The Nosorog series was developed on the exoskeleton base design with the goal of improving protective capabilities and solving some of its inherent flaws. The exact origins of Nosorog armors are unknown. They are rumored to have been the brainchild of a now-deceased stalker named "Fang", whose designs were later claimed by all sorts of powerful factions across the Zone. If regular exoskeletons allow stalkers to feel like a light vehicle, the Nosorog almost makes them believe they're a main battle tank, able to withstand incredible punishment while carrying tremendous ordnance. Rarely seen in use around the Zone.\n \n

A high-tech, next-generation exoskeleton armor, featuring a double-reinforced Kevlar exosuit, a tactical vest with Class IV inserts, and an additional layering of ballistic-weave, supported by powered limbs and servomotors. The Nosorog series was developed on the exoskeleton base design with the goal of improving protective capabilities and solving some of its inherent flaws. This model has been lightly modified by Freedom technicians. The exact origins of Nosorog armors are unknown. They are rumored to have been the brainchild of a now-deceased stalker named "Fang", whose designs were later claimed by all sorts of powerful factions across the Zone. If regular exoskeletons allow stalkers to feel like a light vehicle, the Nosorog almost makes them believe they're a main battle tank, able to withstand incredible punishment while carrying tremendous ordnance. Rarely seen in use around the Zone.\n \n

A camouflaged outfit designed to blend the wearer into natural surroundings, primarily for stealth operations. The suit is made from a durable, lightweight synthetic fabric covered with jute or burlap strips and colored to match various environments like forests, grasslands, or deserts. The materials provide excellent concealment but offer minimal ballistic protection. The design allows for significant mobility while reducing the wearer's visibility to enemies. Commonly used by snipers, scouts, and reconnaissance units operating in the Zone.\n \n
